title: Firestick
description: Firestick, wood with a reed sheath decorated with Abrus precatorius seeds: Australasia, Australia, Australian Aboriginal, 19th to 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Wood; reed sheath decorated with prayer-liquorice seeds
interpretation: A common method for making fire was to rub two pieces of wood together. These firesticks have a cover to keep them dry, which is decorated with red seeds.

title: Vessel
description: Vessel (coolamon), roughly elliptical with raised sides, pigmented red with brown stripes, wood: Australasia, Australia, Western Australia, Kimberley, Derby, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Derby, Kimberley Region, Western Australia, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Wood; grooved and painted with raised sides
interpretation: Coolamon are wooden dishes moulded over a fire to give them their curved shape. They are used to transport food and water, or as baby-carriers.
associations: Collector: Clement, Emile Louis Bruno, Dr, 1844 - 1928
references: Clement, E. (1904) Ethnographical Notes of the Western-Australian Aborigines. (with a descriptive catalogue of a collection of ethnographical objects from Western Australia by J. D. E. Schmeltz) In Internationales Archiv für Ethnographie; 16, pp. 1-27

title: Bag
description: String bag (dilly-bag), plant fibre: Australasia, Australia, Queensland, 19th or 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Queensland, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Twine
interpretation: Across Australia's Northern Territory, Aboriginal women still make string bags to carry food and fish. The bags are lined with feathers or animal fur to stop food falling out through the holes. When making string bags, women sit on the ground and use their outstretched legs as a frame.

title: Basket
description: Basket, bicornual with handle, cane plant: Australasia, Australia, Queensland, Port Douglas, Australian Aboriginal, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Port Douglas, Queensland, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Cane
interpretation: Crescent-shaped cane baskets were unique to the Queensland region of Australia. They had to be constructed quickly, because after a few days the cane became too tough to weave. These baskets were used to collect food, and in times of flooding, women used them to catch small fish.

title: Basket
description: Basket with black, red and yellow strips running through coil, representing the colours of the Australian Aboriginal flag, plant fibre: Australasia, Australia, South Australia, Pukatja, Australian Aboriginal: Pitjantjatjara, by Alison (Milyika) Carroll, 2007
production_information: Carroll, Alison Milyika, 1958 (b.), Basket weaver, Pukatja, South Australia, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Black, red and yellow strips running through coil
copyright: © Alison (Milyika) Carroll; Image © National Museums Scotland
interpretation: Colourful coiled baskets are popular tourist items, available in many shops and galleries of Aboriginal art. Natural dyes are used to create bright purples, pinks, yellows and reds. The baskets are created by coiling bunches of fibre strands and are expanded and shaped upwards as the work proceeds.

title: Necklace
description: Necklace consisting of small oblongs of pearl shell perforated and strung on cordage: Australasia, Australia, Queensland, Cape York Peninsula, Australian Aboriginal, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Cape York Peninsula, Queensland, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Oblongs of nautilus shell perforated and strung on twine
interpretation: In Aboriginal culture, the fibre cord is the most important part of a necklace. It symbolizes the connections between people. Necklaces are worn by men and woman in ceremonies. Shell necklaces are valuable and traded inland across Australia. Great effort and skill went into collecting, cleaning, drilling and threading these tiny shells.

title: Sinew
description: Sinews (candarra) of emu and kangaroo: Australasia, Australia, Western Australia, Australian Aboriginal, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Western Australia, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Emu and kangaroo sinews
interpretation: In the Australian desert, survival depends upon knowing how to manage resources. Every part of an animal can be useful. Traditionally, sinew from a kangaroo or emu was used to secure spearheads to handles or as thread for making a necklace. The introduction of sheep by Europeans has totally transformed the Australian landscape.
associations: Collector: Clement, Emile Louis Bruno, Dr, 1844 - 1928

title: Cooking vessel
description: Cooking vessel with cord for suspension, wood from Manuka tree: Australasia, Australia, Australian Aboriginal, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Wen or knot of the manookus scrub, with cord suspenders
interpretation: These bowls are made from Manuka or tea tree wood, which is common in parts of Australia. Knots from a trunk have been hollowed out to create the bowls.

title: Mask
description: Mask, in the form of a thunderbird, operated by cords by the wearer to open to reveal a human face inside, part of an adult Kwakiutl style transformation mask and costume, carved cedar: Kwakwaka'wakw, North America, Canada, British Columbia, Fort Rupert, by Calvin Hunt, 1998 - 1999
production_information: Hunt, Calvin, 1956 (b.), Master carver, Fort Rupert, Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada, North America
physical_description: Red cedar, carved; painted in black, red, green and yellow

exhibitions.name: Heaven and Hell and other worlds of the dead

interpretation: The dance performances of the Nuu-cha-nulth and Kwakwaka wakw people are inherited privileges which dramatically re-enact events from oral histories. Calvin Hunt (born 1956) received the rights to the Thunderbird crest, stories and dance outfit through his mother, Emma Hunt. The Thunderbird mask opens to show a human face, referring to the transformation of an ancestor who helped the Great Chief during a terrible flood. Hunt danced the mask and outfit in Port Hardy, Vancouver Island, before they were sent to Scotland.
associations: Port Hardy, British Columbia, Canada, North America
references: Sheridan, A (ed) 2000 Heaven and Hell and other worlds of the dead 2000 NMS Publishing, p110 (entry written by Dale Idiens)
Knowles, Chantal. 2003 ‘Commissioning Art: Objects, Ethnography and Contemporary Collecting’ Journal of Museum Ethnography 15: 57-66
Realm of the Spirits Catalogue, 2003

title: Canoe
description: Model 'head' canoe, of cedar wood, painted with crest designs: North America, Canada, British Columbia, Haida Gwaii, Haida, early 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Haida Gwaii, British Columbia, Canada, North America
interpretation: Northwest Coast people are maritime communities, their life and values symbolized as much by the oceangoing canoe as the totem pole. Traditionally, canoes were used in trade, war and visits for feasting. The Haida might paddle trading fleets on a round trip of 2000 kilometres and some sea-going canoes reached up to 20 metres in length.
collection_places: Haida Gwaii, British Columbia, Canada, North America

title: Halibut hook
description: Halibut hook, formed of two pieces of wood lashed together in a V-shape, one limb carved in the likeness of a bird in flight and carrying the line, the other carrying the bone barb secured by a lashing: North America, Canada, British Columbia, or USA, Alaska, Northern Northwest Coast, late 19th - early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, British Columbia, Canada, North America; Alaska, USA, North America
physical_description: Two pieces of wood lashed together in a V-shape, one limb carved as a bird in flight, the other carrying the bone barb secured by a lashing
interpretation: Fishing methods were adapted to different fish species, and a range of spears and fish hooks were used. Most important were the seasonal runs of salmon. Salmon was eaten fresh but also smoked and dried, preserving it for the winter and feasting. Northern style halibut hooks were sturdy, with carved images of helping spirits.

title: Harpoon head
description: Barbed harpoon head, of bone, with line of wrapped sinew attached: North America, Canada, British Columbia, Vancouver Island, Nuu-chah-nulth, late 18th century
production_information: Unknown, Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada, North America
physical_description: Bone; gut lashing; line of wrapped sinew
interpretation: Amongst the Nuu-chah-nulth, whaling started in the spring extending into summer. It was the occupation of the nobility and led by a chief who was ritually prepared. Whales were hunted in canoes with harpoon lines and seal floats. Feasting followed, but only after the soul of the whale had departed.
collection_places: Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada, North America

title: Club
description: Sword club, or chitoolth, of walrus bone, with handle carved to depict a Thunderbird: North America, Canada, Vancouver Island, Nuu-chah-nulth, late 18th - early 19th century
production_information: Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada, North America
physical_description: Sword club made from walrus bone; handle carved to depict a Thunderbird
interpretation: Traditionally, kin groups were ranked in relation to each other. Village layouts reflected this hierarchy, and poles used in front of houses showed crest animals and ancestors.Chiefs were the highest ranking members of a kin group on the basis of age and wealth. They made the most important decisions concerning warfare and peace-making.

title: Headdress, chief's
description: Chief's headdress, with Bear crest frontlet on a cap, of carved and painted wood, decorated with feathers, sea lion whiskers and ermine: North America, USA, southern Alaska, Tlingit, c. 1860s
production_information: Unknown, Southern Alaska, Alaska, USA, North America
interpretation: Chiefs owned symbols of wealth and rank. They carried ceremonial staffs on formal occasions and wore complex headdresses with carved frontlets displaying crests. These frontlets brought together the power of high-ranking chiefs, through the use of sea-lion whiskers, abalone shell, ermine skin and feathers, with the stories of their ancestors.

title: Hat
description: Hat, of conoidal shape with flat top, woven from fir root fibres, with chinstrap of coarse red fabric, painted externally in black, red and pale blue, with a crest design representing a bear: North America, Canada, British Columbia, Haida Gwaii, Haida, Charles and Isabella Edenshaw, after 1873-1920
production_information: Unknown, Haida Gwaii, British Columbia, Canada, North America
physical_description: Woven from fir root fibres, painted externally in black, red and pale blue; chinstrap of coarse red fabric
interpretation: Hats, aprons, cedar and wool robes are still used for social and ceremonial gatherings by community members. They are decorated with bold symbolic designs showing animal crests. Crest designs highlight animal traits, such as the bear's teeth and paws or the killer whale's fins. These are familiar to all, enabling immediate recognition of kin and clan.
references: Pacific Northwest Native American Art, ed. Wright, R.K.
collection_places: Haida Gwaii, British Columbia, Canada, North America

title: Chest
description: Bentwood chest, of rectangular shape, of wood, with long sides carved in shallow relief heightened with red, brown, black and green pigments, possibly with Bear and Beaver crests: North America, Canada, British Columbia or USA, Alaska, Northern Northwest Coast, late 19th century
production_information: Unknown, British Columbia, Canada, North America; Alaska, USA, North America
physical_description: Wood; long sides carved in shallow relief heightened with red, brown, black and green pigments with a design probably representing the beaver
interpretation: Large steam-bent chests were owned by the wealthy and specially commissioned. They were considered heirlooms, used for storing gifts, regalia and ritual objects that families held by title. Made of cedar, they were masterpieces of craftsmanship. The relief carving and painting followed formalized rules of design, including abstracted double-eyed faces, nostrils and limbs.

title: Ladle
description: Ladle, of red cedar, with a deep scoop tapering to a handle with extremity carved in the likeness of the head of a bear, the bowl painted with an incomplete design of a bear's head in red pigment: North America, Canada, British Columbia or USA, Alaska, Northern Northwest Coast, late 19th century
production_information: Unknown, British Columbia, Canada, North America; Alaska, USA, North America
physical_description: Red cedar; bowl painted in red pigment with an incomplete design of a bear's head
interpretation: Potlatch hosts were visibly generous, serving large quantities of relished foods. Great hospitality honoured and influenced guests who had travelled far to attend and act as witnesses. Regalia, fine cutlery with family crests and carved dishes were brought out.

title: Dish
description: Boat-shaped dish, of wood, carved in the likeness of a beaver, the ears inlaid with opercula, the rim with lozenges of palioth's shell: North America, Canada, British Columbia or USA, Alaska, Tlingit, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, British Columbia, Canada, North America; Alaska, USA, North America
physical_description: Wood; ears inlaid with opercula, rim with lozenges of palioth's shell
interpretation: Exquisitely carved dishes were signs of wealth. Bowls were made from solid blocks of wood. Some were flared with parallel grooves on the sides and crests at both ends. Smaller bowls were used to hold candlefish (oolachen) oil, used as a condiment for dried salmon.
references: Pacific Northwest Native American Art, ed. Wright, R.K.

title: Headpiece
description: Headpiece, or mask, of carved and painted wood, representing a raven, and a hawk on the underside: North America, Canada, British Columbia, Vancouver Island, Central 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada, North America
physical_description: Wood, carved and painted; two pieces of copper inset on beak
interpretation: In the past as today, relationships between people, the natural and the supernatural world were recounted in dance and song. Masks were commissioned and performed as inherited privileges by those initiated into different societies.
references: Pacific Northwest Native American Art, ed. Wright, R.K.
collection_places: Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada, North America

title: Rattle
description: Rattle, consisting of two hollow hemispheres of wood, decorated with characteristic designs showing the bear and the thunderbird, secured with ties and containing stone pellets, the handle is bound by a length of withy: North America, USA, Alaska or Canada, British Columbia, Tlingit or Tsimshian, mid 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Alaska, USA, North America; British Columbia, Canada, North America
interpretation: Rattles were important shamanic possessions, though also carried by chiefs. This round rattle has a Bear with a protruding tongue on one side and a Thunderbird on the other.

title: Soul catcher
description: Soul catcher, of hollow, cylindrical form, of bone with open ends, slit and expanded in form of the jaws of monsters, with inlaid fragments of haliotis shell, used for capturing the souls of sick people: North America, Canada, British Columbia, Skeena River, Tsimshian, mid 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Skeena River, British Columbia, Canada, North America
physical_description: Bone; inlaid fragments of haliotis shell
interpretation: Shamans wore carved ivory or bone ornaments. These were personal, depicting animal spirits and helpers the shaman encountered, or expressing the content of dreams and visions. Double-headed hollow bone pendants were known as 'soul catchers', because they trapped the errant souls that caused illness before curing the patient.
associations: Rae of Orkney Collection; Collector: Rae, John, Dr, 1813 - 1893
collection_places: Skeena River, British Columbia, Canada, North America
credit: On loan from The University of Edinburgh

title: Bowl
description: Bowl, oval with curved sides and pointed ends: Japan, Hokkaido, Nibutani, Ainu, by Kaizawa Kōichi, 2000
production_information: Kaizawa Koichi, 1946 (b.), Carver, Nibutani, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
copyright: © Kaizawa Kōichi; Image © National Museums Scotland
interpretation: From his teens, Kaizawa Kōichi (born 1946) was interested in Ainu crafts, making them himself. In 1997, as a plaintiff in the trial concerning the construction of a dam in Nibutani, he won a ruling that the dam was illegal. This ruling was the first time that the Ainu were publicly acknowledged as an indigenous people.

title: Hanging
description: Diamond-shaped wall hanging of maple wood, form carved to suggest a textile with abstract designs in low relief on surface, uppermost corner carved as if bent over to hold cord loop: Japan, Hokkaido, Nibutani, Ainu, by Kaizawa Tōru, 2006
production_information: Kaizawa Toru, 1958 (b.), Carver, Nibutani, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
copyright: © Kaizawa Tōru; Image © National Museums Scotland
interpretation: Kaizawa Tōru (born 1958) grew up watching his parents and relatives practise carving and weaving as their livelihood. Kaizawa started to carve when he was 18, but it was not until he was 30 that he began carving traditional Ainu crafts. Gradually he developed his own, new style which incorporated traditional Ainu patterns.

title: Tamasay
description: Necklace (tamasay), beads of coloured glass, lead and engraved brass, worn by a woman: Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Coloured glass, lead and brass
interpretation: On ceremonial occasions, women traditionally wore beaded necklaces called tamasay. Light reflecting from the beads was believed to ward off malicious spirits. Earrings, or ninkari, were also worn to stop such spirits entering the ears.

title: Mat
description: Mat, rushes secured with cord, used for offerings made during the bear ceremony (iyomante): Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th to early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Rushes

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: Food and drink play an important role in Ainu ceremonies and celebrations. In the bear ceremony, food was traditionally offered to the bear spirit and shared by the community. When the bear spirit returned to the spirit world, he shared the food he had received with the other spirit-gods.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 133 (p.78)

title: Prayer stick
description: Prayer stick (ikupasuy), wooden stick with pointed end, abstract designs carved in low relief and coated in red and black lacquer, probably carved by an Ainu craftsman then lacquered by a Japanese artisan, used in Ainu ceremonies: Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Wood; one side carved with broad red scrolls on a brown scale-diapered field

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: The Ainu obtained objects decorated with black and red lacquer from their Japanese neighbours in exchange for furs and fish. These were treasured possessions, used in ceremonies and handed down through families. This prayer stick was probably carved by an Ainu craftsman and then lacquered by a Japanese artisan.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 130 (p.39)

title: Headdress
description: Headdress (sapaunpe), circlet of twisted wood shavings with pieces of brown cotton, wooden representation of a bear's head at front, worn by men in ceremonies: Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th to early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Elm bark, brown cotton, shavings, bear's head carved in wood

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: Ainu ceremonies are led by community elders. Men and women wear richly decorated robes. Women wear headbands and men wear headdresses called sapaunpe. These are often decorated with a carved animal figure, here in the shape of a bear.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 209 (p.67)

title: Ceremonial stick
description: Shaved ceremonial stick (inaw), wooden stick with twisted shavings hanging down, offered to Ainu gods (kamuy) during ceremonies. Particular shapes are carved for different kamuy - this shape is called kike chinoye inaw: Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th to early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Dogwood; twisted shavings

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: Today, as in the past, shaved sticks, inaw, are used in Ainu ceremonies and attached to outdoor altars called nusa. Inaw symbolize birds and accompany prayers on their journey to the spirit world. They are carved into different shapes depending on the spirit-gods being honoured.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 37 (p.74)

title: Prayer stick
description: Prayer stick with shaved decoration (kike ikupasuy), wooden stick with pointed end, attached shavings on upper surface, used in the Ainu bear ceremony: Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th to early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Willow wood; shavings attached

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: Shaved prayer sticks, kike ikupasuy, were made for the bear ceremony. The pointed 'tongues' were dipped to offer beer or rice wine to the spirit-gods. Other prayer sticks could be reused, but kike ikupasuy were usually destroyed or placed on an altar as offerings after the ceremony.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 30 (p.72)

title: Arrow
description: Ceremonial arrow (heper ay), notched shaft with feather flight, blunt wooden tip carved with abstract designs, used in the bear ceremony (iyomante): Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th to early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Carved wood point; shaft of reed or wood notched and feathered

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: Blunted arrows, called flower arrows or heper ay, were released at the beginning of the bear ceremony. These beautifully decorated arrows were believed to be cherished by the bear spirit and were one of the many gifts given to him during the ceremony.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 55 (p.70-71)

title: Trough
description: Feeding trough for bear (heper nima), hollowed out wood with projecting handle, used to feed young bears captured for the bear ceremony (iyomante): Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th to early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Wood

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: Captured cubs were honoured guests and given food and toys. Younger cubs were often brought indoors, but as they grew they were fed in their cages.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 35 (p.70)

title: Spring-bow trap
description: Bow, part of spring-bow trap with trigger (A.1909.499.50 A), wooden bow with cord, used for hunting: Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th to early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Wood

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: The Ainu hunted and trapped deer, bears, foxes and otters in the forests. Deer were an important source of meat and were hunted with hand bows and traps. Of all these animals, bears were the most sacred and bear hunting was strictly controlled within the community.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 61 (p.84)

title: Fishing spear
description: Tip of fishing spear (marek), wood with pivoting iron hook and sealskin line: Sakhalin, Ainu, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Sakhalin, Siberia, Russia, Eastern Europe
physical_description: Iron hook; sealskin line; white wood handle
interpretation: Fishing was vital to Ainu communities. Salmon and trout returned to the rivers to spawn in vast numbers, so villages were built near the spawning grounds. Annual ceremonies welcomed the first salmon and sent its spirit back in the hope that it would return the following year.

title: Belt
description: Woven nettle fibre belt decorated with coloured cloth and blue glass beads, carrying seal and sharkskin pouches, antler tip and two knives: Sakhalin, Ainu, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Sakhalin, Siberia, Russia, Eastern Europe
physical_description: Nettle thread with broader ends of coloured cloth / sealskin pouch / sharkskin purse / antler tip
interpretation: This belt is a combination of elements, including seal-and sharkskin pouches, an antler tip and two knives. These items would have been used by Sakhalin Ainu.

title: String of beads
description: String of beads attaching lid to poison holder (A.1909.499.41), double string of glass beads, various colours: Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th to early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Variegated glass beads

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: Ainu communities living in Hokkaido used poison-tipped arrows for hunting. Poison was made from the plant monkshood and ingredients such as tobacco and poisonous spiders.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 156 (p.84)

title: Ekamasune
description: Bag (ekamasune), woven rushes with chevron design and patterned indigo fabric panels at ends: Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Rushes
interpretation: While groups of hunters travelled into the mountains, taking what they needed to make camp, the rest of the community, including women, children and the elderly, gathered wild plants from the area around the village. These plants complemented the food obtained by hunting and fishing and provided materials for crafts.

title: Robe
description: Robe, striped elm-bark cloth (attush) with abstract designs in blue cotton calico applique and embroidery around hem, cuffs and collar, worn by a man: Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th to early 20th century
production_information: Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Woven elm bark and applied blue calico embroidered with scrolling patterns

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: The patterns on this robe are concentrated around the collar, cuffs and hem, focusing their protective power at these 'weak' points where harmful spirits might enter.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 77 (p.60)

title: Headband
description: Headband, indigo cotton embroidered with abstract designs in green, pink and white: Japan, Hokkaido, Tomakomai, Ainu, by Sunazawa Yumiko, 2002
production_information: Sunazawa Yumiko, 2002 (fl.), Tomakomai-shi, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Cotton dyed indigo blue and embroidered in green, pink and white silk
copyright: © Yumiko Sunazawa; Image © National Museums Scotland
interpretation: These items were created by two artists, mother and daughter, who embroider in the Ainu tradition. The leggings were made by Sunazawa Yoeko, who visited this Museum in 2002. The headband was made by her daughter, Yumiko.

title: Loom
description: Back-strap loom of wood, with roll of striped elm bark cloth: Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th to early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: Women traditionally wove cloth using a backstrap loom. The wooden brace fits around the weaver's back and is used to keep the threads on the loom taut. The wooden parts of the loom, thread winders and beaters, were carved by men and feature typical Ainu designs.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 224 (p.68)

title: Pons ikayop
description: Model quiver (pons ikayop), wood with carved abstract designs, used as charms or placed into burials: Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th to early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Carved wood

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: These carvings are miniature versions of the quivers which Ainu men carried for hunting. Sometimes used as charms by the living, they were also placed into men's graves for their next life in the spirit world.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 136 (p. 33)

title: Prayer stick
description: Prayer stick (ikupasuy), wooden stick with pointed end, carved with abstract designs in low relief, used in Ainu ceremonies to deliver prayers: Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th to early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Carved wood

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: Ikupasuy or prayer sticks are sacred objects used in Ainu ceremonies. Lines carved at each end are similar to family crests and identify the owner, while symbols sometimes carved on the reverse have private meaning. The central section is carved freely and may include animals such as bears and whales, or representations of ceremonial objects.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 109 (p.41)

title: Knife
description: Knife (makiri) with metal blade set into wooden handle: Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th to early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Iron blade, wood handle

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: Both men and women carried knives, makiri. A craftsman's skill was judged by the decoration on his knife. When a man wished to marry a woman, he carved a knife especially for her. If she wore this, it showed that she had accepted his proposal.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 1 (p.45)

title: Tobacco box
description: Tobacco box with pipe holder, wooden with bone toggle, carved abstract designs: Japan, Hokkaido, Ainu, 19th to early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Hokkaido, Japan, East Asia
physical_description: Carved wood; bone toggle

exhibitions.name: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection
locations: Historical Museum of Hokkaido
Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

interpretation: Ainu pipe holders look very similar to prayer sticks, but only ever have abstract designs. The small box, hung from the belt, held imported tobacco.
references: A Scottish Physician's View: Craft and Spirit of the Ainu from the N. G. Munro Collection (2002), no. 150 (p.48-49)

title: Mani stone
description: Mani stone (stone tablet), circular stone carved with 'om mani padme hum' (Tibetan Buddhist mantra) set into lotus flower petals, for setting at religious sites in the landscape: India, Ladakh, Tibetan, 19th century AD
production_information: Ladakh, Jammu and Kashmir, India, South Asia
physical_description: Stone
interpretation: For Tibetan Buddhists, the act of walking can be a form of meditation. As pilgrims walk, they recite mantras, count them on beads, and turn hand wheels packed with printed prayers. Carved stones are used to mark places of importance, such as sacred monuments and mountain passes.

title: Tsa-tsa
description: Tsa-tsa (religious offering), moulded cone of sun-baked clay in shape of chorten (Buddhist monument), used as offering or carried for spiritual protection: India, Ladakh, Basgo, Tibetan, late 19th to early 20th century AD
production_information: Basgo, Leh, Ladakh, Jammu and Kashmir, India, South Asia
physical_description: Purplish clay
interpretation: This case was probably carried by a travelling monk. When the monk reached a village or camp, people could venerate the deities depicted on the moulded clay tsa-tsa inside. The case may have been in use for many years.

title: Shrine case
description: Shrine case with painting, wooden case decorated with foliate design in gold on red, painting of Buddhist figure within visible through shrine-shaped aperture in lid: India, Ladakh, Leh, Tibetan, collected c. 1900 AD
production_information: Leh, Ladakh, Jammu and Kashmir, India, South Asia
physical_description: Painted and gilt wood
interpretation: The image in this case was painted for the collector, Lilian Le Mesurier, as the monks who gave her the case would not part with the original.
associations: Depicted: Bukola, Abbot of Spittok Monastery, Le Mesurier Collection

title: Altar, portable
description: Altar, gilded copper table with front panel decorated with Kirtimukha (Face of Majesty) and set with turquoise, the trestle legs and front panel fold into the table top for transport: Tibet, late 19th century AD
production_information: Tibet Autonomous Region, China, East Asia
physical_description: Sheet copper, hammered and gilded; band of applique ovoid copper plaques and rosettes of turquoise inlay
interpretation: Most Tibetan tents and houses have an altar for Buddhist statues, butter lamps and offering bowls, above which a thangka painting might be displayed. These altars are a smaller version of those found in temples and monasteries. The sacred images are placed at different heights to indicate respect.

title: Drilbu
description: Drilbu (handbell) of bronze, domed chamber with cast borders of dorje (sceptres) and kirtimukha (monster faces) in relief, handle features face of Prajna-paramita (deity) surmounted by eight-pronged dorje finial, in Tibetan Buddhist rituals the bell represents wisdom or emptiness: Tibet, 19th to early 20th century AD
production_information: Tibet Autonomous Region, China, East Asia
physical_description: Cast bronze chased with mystic symbols
interpretation: The daily offerings made at altars in homes and temples require a range of bowls, ewers and butter lamps. Monks use other ritual objects, such as the dorje and drilbu or thunderbolt and bell. Paired together, the dorje and drilbu represent the union of compassion and wisdom required to achieve enlightenment.

title: Gau
description: Gau (amulet box), circular metal box with glazed lid, containing gilded clay relief of a Buddhist deity, worn by soldiers for spiritual protection: China, Tibet Autonomous Region, Xigaze Prefecture, Yadong County, 19th century AD
production_information: Yadong County, Xigaze Prefecture, Tibet Autonomous Region, China, East Asia
physical_description: Copper; gilt terracotta relief
interpretation: Amulet cases, known as gau, are worn by Tibetans for spiritual protection every day. Gau contain images of deities, written prayers or other sacred items. The materials and symbols used on the case have special significance and offer different forms of protection.

title: Tsa-tsa
description: Tsa-tsa (religious offering), moulded cone of sun-baked clay in shape of chorten (Buddhist monument), used as offering or carried for spiritual protection: India, Ladakh, Tibetan, late 19th to early 20th century AD
production_information: Ladakh, Jammu and Kashmir, India, South Asia
physical_description: White clay
interpretation: Tsa-tsa are small tokens of moulded clay which can be carried in a gau or left as offerings. Some tsa-tsa are made to resemble sacred monuments called chorten, which are important features of the Tibetan landscape. Other tsa-tsa are decorated with images of Buddhist deities.

title: Printing block
description: Printing block of wood, square, carved with circular design enclosing lotus flower and Tibetan script, used for printing paper amulets: Tibet, late 19th century AD
production_information: Tibet Autonomous Region, China, East Asia
physical_description: Wood
interpretation: In Tibet, woodblock printed charms sold by monks were used to ward off illness and misfortune. Dough moulds were carried by trained practitioners who travelled from village to village. The dough cakes made with these moulds were presented to deities to gain their favour.

title: Ngayab
description: Ngayab (flywhisk) consisting of a yak's tail with wooden handle: Tibet, late 19th to early 20th century AD
production_information: Tibet Autonomous Region, China, East Asia
physical_description: Yak's tail, wood handle
interpretation: Yak are treasured by their owners as they provide wool, leather, milk and meat. Butter and yoghurt made from yak's milk are both important to the Tibetan diet. Yak dung can be dried for use as fuel.

title: Hook
description: Hook of iron, S-shaped with serpent design: Tibet, early 20th century AD
production_information: Tibet Autonomous Region, China, East Asia
physical_description: Iron; slight engraved ornament
interpretation: Farmers use yak to plough their fields, while traders and nomads use them to transport goods. Traders traditionally loaded their yak caravans with furs, salt, hides and wool, which were exchanged for Chinese tea, silk, silver and other items.

title: Girdle
description: Girdle and chopstick case, four chased and openwork brass links, with one hanging link suspending wooden case with gold damascened steel mounts with foliate design, part of an eating set (girdle, case, two chopsticks and knife) worn and used by Tibetan women: possibly manufactured in China, collected in Tibet, Tibetan, 19th century AD
production_information: China, East Asia; Tibet Autonomous Region, China, East Asia
physical_description: Brass, chased and pierced
interpretation: Most personal items used by Tibetan nomads could be hooked onto a belt or tucked into the folds of a robe. Working away from home, in the fields or on long journeys, people needed to make sure they had essential items to hand.

title: Robe
description: Robe of green cotton lined with blue, with bands of red and embroidered white silk on cuffs and hem, part of a woman's outfit: Tibet, Amdo, late 19th to early 20th century AD
production_information: Amdo, Tibet, East Asia
physical_description: Green cotton lined with blue; broad band of red silk and a narrow white silk embroidery on the sleeves and the front and bottom of skirt
interpretation: Women in Amdo regularly wore spectacular outfits like this until the 1940s. The full outfit included a long back ornament with two side ornaments and a pair of hair covers. The robe here is of Chinese cotton, but a more usual robe would be a wool or sheepskin Tibetan chuba.

title: Tsampa bag
description: Tsampa bag of red leather, with drawstring mouth and striped fabric around middle, for carrying tsampa (roasted barley flour, staple Tibetan food): China, Sichuan Province, Garze Prefecture, Dege, Tibetan, c. 2003 AD
production_information: Dege County, Garze Prefecture, Sichuan Province, China, East Asia
interpretation: When nomads strike camp, everything has to be packed up and strapped to an animal or to someone's back for the journey. As well as taking their personal possessions, nomads also use sturdy bags to carry tsampa (roast barley flour), which is a staple food in Tibet.

title: Tea vessel
description: Vessel of elm wood, tall cylinder with brass fittings and dragon-shaped handle, used for serving tea in a Tibetan Buddhist monastery: India, Ladakh, Hemis Monastery, Tibetan, 19th century AD
production_information: Hemis Monastery, Ladakh, Jammu and Kashmir, India, South Asia
physical_description: Elm bound with brass; dragon handle of brass and copper
interpretation: Big vessels were needed in Tibetan monasteries for serving tea to the often large monastic populations. Tibetan tea made with yak butter and salt helped to sustain monks during lengthy rituals and meditations.

title: Churn
description: Churn for tea or butter, bamboo vessel with brass, rattan and iron bands, and carrying cord, and with unattached cane churning stick: Tibet, late 19th century AD
production_information: Tibet Autonomous Region, China, East Asia
physical_description: Bamboo; brass, iron and rattan bands; churning stick of cane
interpretation: In 1893, Annie Royle Taylor braved rugged terrain in her attempt to reach Lhasa the Tibetan capital. Forced to turn back just three days away from the city, she later returned to Tibet to continue her work as a missionary. The items here were used by Taylor to make fortifying yak butter tea.

title: Teacup
description: Cup of white jade, with straight sides flaring to mouth and short narrow footring, part of a set with silver stand and copper cover, used for drinking tea: Tibetan, late 19th century AD
production_information: Tibet Autonomous Region, China, East Asia
physical_description: Jade
interpretation: Hospitality has long been a key feature of life in Tibet. Tableware crafted from precious materials such as jade and porcelain was used for serving tea to guests. Being a lavish host showed respect for the guest, while also displaying personal wealth.

title: Pagor
description: Pagor (headdress) consisting of cane and red cloth loops decorated with turquoise, coral and strings of pearl-like glass beads, with two attached human hair plaits, style of headdress worn by women in southern Tibet: Tibet, 19th century AD
production_information: Tibet Autonomous Region, China, East Asia
physical_description: Vertical half-loop of cane covered with red cloth, circlets of red cloth mounted with beads of red coral and turquoise, and silver charms set with turquoise; two bands of white glass beads, two plaits of human hair
interpretation: The amazing headdress, or pagor, dominates this outfit. It is decorated with coral, turquoise and glass beads that imitate pearls. The wearer would have secured the headdress with cords and hooks.

title: Earring
description: Earring, one of a pair, silver hoop with teardrop-shaped turquoise decorations, and pendant with coral beads and granulated metal decoration, worn by women: China, Tibet Autonomous Region, Lhasa, Tibetan, 19th century AD
production_information: Lhasa, Tibet Autonomous Region, China, East Asia
physical_description: Silver; turquoise floral device, coral beads
interpretation: The earrings worn by men and women indicated their wealth and rank, and could signal their occupation. Though other sources were used, turquoise from Iran and deep red Italian coral were highly prized. Precious stones and other materials were also imitated.

title: Spoon
description: Spoon of silver, stem decorated with engraved scale pattern, animal head terminus, and central rosette set with turquoise stone: India, West Bengal, Tibetan, 1938 AD
production_information: West Bengal, India, South Asia
physical_description: Silver; incised on bowl with a shell motif and on stem with overlapping scales; handle decorated with a foliate motif in high relief; rosette at centre set with a single turquoise
interpretation: Like nomads, Tibetans living in towns and cities carried implements on their belts. These practical items included decorated spoons and chopstick sets.
associations: Collector: Taylor, George, Sir, 1904 - 1993; Kew Gardens Botanical Expedition to Tibet

title: Tobacco-pipe
description: Tobacco-pipe with metal bowl, slender wooden stem, and glass mouthpiece imitating a dzi (patterned chalcedony bead): China, 19th to early 20th century, collected in Tibet
production_information: China, East Asia
physical_description: Brass head, black wood stem, imitation jade mouthpiece
interpretation: This snuff bottle and pipe are decorated with materials popular in Tibet. The pipe's mouthpiece is an imitation chalcedony bead or dzi. Patterned dzi are found in the ground and Tibetans have many explanations for their origin. One suggests that dzi are worms or insects which turn to stone when discovered.
associations: Tibet Autonomous Region, China, East Asia

title: Pen-case
description: Pen-case of brass with silver mount, openwork foliate designs on front and hexagons on reverse, and loop for suspension, and with separate cover, used to carry bamboo writing pen: Tibet, 19th to early 20th century AD
production_information: Tibet Autonomous Region, China, East Asia
physical_description: Brass; leafy scrollwork on one side and a network of hexagons on the other
interpretation: In Tibet, reading and writing were essential for the study of Buddhist texts and for civil administration. Pen cases were a mark of status and learning.

title: Dish
description: Shallow oval dish, of woven split spruce roots, decorated with red and blue quills: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Tłı̨chǫ, c. 1862
production_information: Unknown, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Woven split spruce roots; decorated with red and blue quills

exhibitions.name: Dogrib: We live securely by the land
location: Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre

interpretation: Drinking cups, food bowls and cooking vessels were made of spruce roots. These were taken from the living tree in spring, then coiled and stitched. Spruce root swells when wet, making containers watertight. In cooking, a basketry kettle was filled with water and raw food, then red-hot rocks were added to boil the mixture.
references: Dè T'a Hoti Ts'eeda: 'We Live Securely by the Land'; An Exhibition of Dene material selected from the collections from National Museums Scotland. Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre, Yellowknife, Northwest Territories, Canada 2006

Idiens, Dale, A catalogue of Northern Athapaskan Indian artefacts in the collection of the Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, Royal Scottish Museum Information Series, Art and Archaeology 3, March 1979

title: Pail
description: Pail, of cut and folded birch bark, stitched with blue and white quills, the rim reinforced by a bent stick lashed with split spruce roots and red, blue and white porcupine quills, has thong carrying strap, used for carrying water or berries: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Great Slave Lake, Fort Rae, Tłı̨chǫ, c. 1860
production_information: Unknown, Fort Rae, Great Slave Lake, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Cut and folded birch bark stitched with blue and white quills, rim reinforced by a bent stick lashed with split spruce roots and red, blue and white porcupine quills. Has thong carrying strap.

exhibitions.name: Dogrib: We live securely by the land
locations: Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre
Carleton University Art Gallery

interpretation: Birchbark is a renewable material which has many uses. The technique used in making containers is straightforward - the bark is cut, folded, and stitched with spruce root. Simple disposable containers are still made today, and some craftswomen decorate baskets with porcupine quillwork for sale as art objects.
references: Dè T’a Hoti Ts’eeda: ‘We Live Securely by the Land’; An Exhibition of Dene material selected from the collections from National Museums Scotland. Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre, Yellowknife, Northwest Territories, Canada 2006

Idiens, Dale, A catalogue of Northern Athapaskan Indian artefacts in the collection of the Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, Royal Scottish Museum Information Series, Art and Archaeology 3, March 1979

title: Dress
description: Dress, of tanned smoked caribou skin, with slit neck and shirt-type collar tying with thongs, and rectangular cape hanging from shoulders across back, decorated with thongs wrapped with red and white porcupine quills, part of a woman's summer outfit: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Great Slave Lake, Tłı̨chǫ, 1860
production_information: Unknown, Great Slave Lake, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Women's summer dress of tanned smoked caribou skin with slit neck and shirt-type collar tying with thongs. Set-in sleeves gathered into cuffs. Lower edge fringed. Rectangular cape hangs from shoulders across back, decorated with thongs wrapped with red and white porcupine quills. Thong fringes at the armhole and sleeve seams, sewn with sinew.

exhibitions.name: Dogrib: We live securely by the land
locations: Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre
Carleton University Art Gallery

interpretation: This outfit of smoked caribou skin was probably everyday wear. It is lightweight and protected the wearer from biting insects. The materials and style are traditional, but some elements, the collar and cuffs, reflect European influence. Decoration is minimal, although the belt of woven porcupine quills is exquisitely worked.
references: The Athabaskans: Strangers of the North. Ottawa: National Museum of Man, 1974. Exhibition catalogue from 'An international travelling exhibition from the collection of the National Museum of Man, Canada, and the Royal Scottish Museum'. cat no. 172

Idiens, Dale, A catalogue of Northern Athapaskan Indian artefacts in the collection of the Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, Royal Scottish Museum Information Series, Art and Archaeology 3, March 1979

Dè T’a Hoti Ts’eeda: ‘We Live Securely by the Land’; An Exhibition of Dene material selected from the collections from National Museums Scotland. Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre, Yellowknife, Northwest Territories, Canada 2006

title: Snowshoe
description: Model snowshoe, one of a pair, of wood and babiche: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Great Slave Lake, Fort Rae, Tłı̨chǫ, c. 1860
production_information: Unknown, Fort Rae, Great Slave Lake, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Model snowshoes with wood frame laced with babiche, frame upturned at front with pointed ends.

exhibitions.name: Dogrib: We live securely by the land
locations: Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre
Carleton University Art Gallery

interpretation: Snowshoes were essential to winter travel and hunting. Styles and sizes varied, made for different types of snow and activity. This style was used for breaking a trail and hunting in deep powdery snow. The wide surface and upturned end prevented the wearer from sinking too deep into the snow.
references: Dè T’a Hoti Ts’eeda: ‘We Live Securely by the Land’; An Exhibition of Dene material selected from the collections from National Museums Scotland. Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre, Yellowknife, Northwest Territories, Canada 2006

Idiens, Dale, A catalogue of Northern Athapaskan Indian artefacts in the collection of the Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, Royal Scottish Museum Information Series, Art and Archaeology 3, March 1979

title: Dog harness
description: Dog harness, consisting of a padded collar of tanned caribou skin with two traces of skin for fastening the dog to the sled, joined by a piece across the back: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Great Slave Lake, Fort Rae, Tłı̨chǫ, c. 1860
production_information: Unknown, Fort Rae, Great Slave Lake, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Model dog harness with padded collar of tanned caribou skin with two traces of skin for fastening the dog to the sled, joined by a piece of skin across the back.

exhibitions.name: Dogrib: We live securely by the land
locations: Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre
Carleton University Art Gallery

interpretation: Dene travelled long distances in winter, carrying infants and household goods on their backs or pulling them on toboggans. Dog teams were introduced by European fur traders and soon became a part of Dene life. Dog teams are still important, though they are mainly kept for competitive racing.
references: The Athabaskans: Strangers of the North. Ottawa: National Museum of Man, 1974. Exhibition catalogue from 'An international travelling exhibition from the collection of the National Museum of Man, Canada, and the Royal Scottish Museum'. cat no. 112

Idiens, Dale, A catalogue of Northern Athapaskan Indian artefacts in the collection of the Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, Royal Scottish Museum Information Series, Art and Archaeology 3, March 1979

Dè T’a Hoti Ts’eeda: ‘We Live Securely by the Land’; An Exhibition of Dene material selected from the collections from National Museums Scotland. Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre, Yellowknife, Northwest Territories, Canada 2006

title: Hunting bag
description: Model hunting bag, of netted babiche, decorated with horizontal bands of red pigment, skin thongs wrapped with yellow quills, and red wool tassels: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Fort Simpson, Tłı̨chǫ, c. 1860
production_information: Unknown, Fort Simpson, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Netted babiche bag decorated with horizontal bands of red pigment, skin thongs wrapped with yellow quills, and red wool tassels; upper edge of tanned caribou skin worked with red, blue and yellow porcupine quills, edge bound with red wool overstitching, with babiche loops for attaching a carrying strap.

exhibitions.name: Dogrib: We live securely by the land
locations: Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre
Carleton University Art Gallery

interpretation: Netted bags made from babiche (caribou rawhide thong) were used to carry game or provisions. Light, durable and expandable, they were slung on the back or under the arm. Decoration was typically on the visible side and accentuated by movement.
references: Dè T’a Hoti Ts’eeda: ‘We Live Securely by the Land’; An Exhibition of Dene material selected from the collections from National Museums Scotland. Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre, Yellowknife, Northwest Territories, Canada 2006

Idiens, Dale, A catalogue of Northern Athapaskan Indian artefacts in the collection of the Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, Royal Scottish Museum Information Series, Art and Archaeology 3, March 1979

title: Hunting bag
description: Hunting bag, of caribou leg-skins, sewn with sinew, with top of tanned caribou skin with a thong drawstring tie: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Fort Simpson, Tłı̨chǫ, c. 1860
production_information: Unknown, Fort Simpson, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Hunting bag made of caribou leg-skins sewn with sinew. Top of tanned caribou skin has a thong drawstring tie.

exhibitions.name: Dogrib: We live securely by the land
locations: Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre
Carleton University Art Gallery

interpretation: No animal part was wasted. The leg skins of caribou and moose, for example, were used to make bags for storing sun-dried or smoke-dried meat.
references: The Athabaskans: Strangers of the North. Ottawa: National Museum of Man, 1974. Exhibition catalogue from 'An international travelling exhibition from the collection of the National Museum of Man, Canada, and the Royal Scottish Museum'. cat no. 91

Idiens, Dale, A catalogue of Northern Athapaskan Indian artefacts in the collection of the Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, Royal Scottish Museum Information Series, Art and Archaeology 3, March 1979

Dè T’a Hoti Ts’eeda: ‘We Live Securely by the Land’; An Exhibition of Dene material selected from the collections from National Museums Scotland. Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre, Yellowknife, Northwest Territories, Canada 2006

title: Bag, smoking
description: Smoking bag, of tanned moose skin, lined with cotton print fabric and decorated with red and blue wool cloth, blue silk ribbon, green and white glass beads, blue and red wool tassels, and a fringe of skin thongs: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Fort Simpson, Tłı̨chǫ, c. 1862
production_information: Unknown, Fort Simpson, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Smoking bag made of tanned moose skin, lined with cotton print fabric and decorated with red and blue wool cloth, blue silk ribbon, green and white glass beads, blue and red wool tassels, and a fringe of skin thongs.

exhibitions.name: Dogrib: We live securely by the land
locations: Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre
Carleton University Art Gallery

interpretation: Smoking bags typically contained supplies like flint, steel, tinder for fire making, a pipe and tobacco. They were suspended from the neck or folded over a belt.
references: Dè T’a Hoti Ts’eeda: ‘We Live Securely by the Land’; An Exhibition of Dene material selected from the collections from National Museums Scotland. Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre, Yellowknife, Northwest Territories, Canada 2006

Idiens, Dale, A catalogue of Northern Athapaskan Indian artefacts in the collection of the Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, Royal Scottish Museum Information Series, Art and Archaeology 3, March 1979

production_information: Unknown, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Model passenger toboggan, or 'cariole,' made of birchwood with upturned front and upright back rest, sides and part of the top filled in with caribou skin parchment, sewn with sinew thread.

exhibitions.name: Dogrib: We live securely by the land
locations: Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre
Carleton University Art Gallery

interpretation: Early toboggans were pulled by hand. This type, introduced by fur traders, was designed to transport passengers and was pulled by a dog team.
references: The Athabaskans: Strangers of the North. Ottawa: National Museum of Man, 1974. Exhibition catalogue from 'An international travelling exhibition from the collection of the National Museum of Man, Canada, and the Royal Scottish Museum'. cat no. 110

description: Model canoe, constructed of birch bark over a wooden frame, the seams stitched with split spruce roots, with gunwales, covered prow and stern with dark green European paint: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Slavey, c. 1862
production_information: Unknown, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Birchbark over a wooden frame, the seams stitched with split spruce roots; gunwales, prow and stern with dark green European paint

exhibitions.name: Dogrib: We live securely by the land
locations: Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre
Carleton University Art Gallery

interpretation: Birchbark canoes were ideal for long-distance travel on lakes and rivers. They were light and easy to steer, and they could be easily repaired from forest materials.
references: The Athabaskans: Strangers of the North. Ottawa: National Museum of Man, 1974. Exhibition catalogue from 'An international travelling exhibition from the collection of the National Museum of Man, Canada, and the Royal Scottish Museum'. cat no. 255

title: Headdress
description: Man's headdress, of tanned caribou skin mounted with seventeen grizzly bears' claws, the edge of the skin band overstitched with quills: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Dene, c. 1859
production_information: Unknown, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Tanned caribou skin band mounted with seventeen bears' claws; edge of the skin band overstitched with quills
interpretation: For the Dene, travelling requires cultural knowledge. People are responsible to the spirits that occupy the land who can help or hinder human activity. Spirits of animals such as bears are especially powerful. Traditionally, a hunter wore bear claws to proclaim his hunting success and his good relations with the spirit world.
references: The Athabaskans: Strangers of the North. Ottawa: National Museum of Man, 1974. Exhibition catalogue from 'An international travelling exhibition from the collection of the National Museum of Man, Canada, and the Royal Scottish Museum'. cat. no. 206

Idiens, Dale, A catalogue of Northern Athapaskan Indian artefacts in the collection of the Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, Royal Scottish Museum Information Series, Art and Archaeology 3, March 1979

title: Charm
description: Charm, consisting of two loops of reindeer leather, bound with quillwork and fringed with feathers, worsted and beads: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Slavey, or Kaska / Nahane c. 1862
production_information: Unknown, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Two loops of reindeer leather bound with quill work and fringed with feathers, worsted, and beads
interpretation: Good relations with the spirits were elicited through dreams and vision quests. Amulets made of materials representing a spirit helper showed this relationship and protected the wearer.
references: Idiens, Dale, A catalogue of Northern Athapaskan Indian artefacts in the collection of the Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, Royal Scottish Museum Information Series, Art and Archaeology 3, March 1979

title: Puberty Drinking Tube
description: Puberty drinking tube, consisting of a swan's wing bone, decorated with a wrapping of braided porcupine quills and a fringe of thongs carrying blue and white beads: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Slavey, or Kaska / Nahane c. 1862
production_information: Unknown, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Bone, swan's pinion; decorated with a wrapping of braided porcupine quills and a fringe of thongs carrying blue and white beads

locations: Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre
Carleton University Art Gallery

interpretation: Dene women carried out essential tasks and their training began in childhood. It intensified at puberty, when young women were thought to be spiritually powerful and lived and travelled apart. During this time they perfected sewing and quillwork skills and learned to be self-sufficient and industrious, qualities much admired in Dene society.
references: The Athabaskans: Strangers of the North. Ottawa: National Museum of Man, 1974. Exhibition catalogue from 'An international travelling exhibition from the collection of the National Museum of Man, Canada, and the Royal Scottish Museum'. cat no. 218

Idiens, Dale, A catalogue of Northern Athapaskan Indian artefacts in the collection of the Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, Royal Scottish Museum Information Series, Art and Archaeology 3, March 1979

Dè T’a Hoti Ts’eeda: ‘We Live Securely by the Land’; An Exhibition of Dene material selected from the collections from National Museums Scotland. Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre, Yellowknife, Northwest Territories, Canada 2006

title: Moccasin
description: Child's moccasin, one of a pair, of animal hide, with beaded vamp in pink, blue and green design, with beaver fur trim: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Tłı̨chǫ, by Madeline Judas, 2007
production_information: Judas, Madeline, 2007 - 2013 (fl.), Maker, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Child's moccasin, one of a pair, with beaded vamp in pink, blue and green design, with beaver fur trim.
interpretation: Traditional Dene craft skills have evolved with the times. Some women carry on the ancient traditions of hide tanning, porcupine quillwork and skin sewing. Smoked hide mittens, moccasins and jackets decorated with floral beadwork are highly prized, given as gifts and worn on special occasions.

title: Tunic
description: Tunic, of tanned caribou skin, decorated with trade beads, dentalium shells and quilled fringe, part of a Gwich'in man's summer outfit: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Gwich'in, c. 1862
production_information: Unknown, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Shirt made of tanned caribou skin with drawstring neck and pointed lower edge, decorated with bands of black glass beads alternating with dentalium shells, thong fringes strung with black, white and red beads, thong fringes wrapped with red, white and blue porcupine quills, and lines of red ochre, sewn with sinew.
interpretation: The plentiful use of trade goods in this summer outfit shows the absorption of imported materials into a distinctively Gwich' in style by the mid-19th century. An outfit with this many trade beads and dentalium shells reflected a man's wealth. It represented his hunting and trading abilities, while advertising his wife's skills as a tanner and seamstress.
references: The Athabaskans: Strangers of the North. Ottawa: National Museum of Man, 1974. Exhibition catalogue from 'An international travelling exhibition from the collection of the National Museum of Man, Canada, and the Royal Scottish Museum. Cat no. 177, p.130, colour plate 34.

Idiens, Dale, A catalogue of Northern Athapaskan Indian artefacts in the collection of the Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, Royal Scottish Museum Information Series, Art and Archaeology 3, March 1979.

Dè T’a Hoti Ts’eeda: ‘We Live Securely by the Land’; An Exhibition of Dene material selected from the collections from National Museums Scotland. Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre, Yellowknife, Northwest Territories, Canada 2006 pp 22-25.
