title: Bag
description: Bag, of leather and sealskin, with bone stretcher and ivory fastenings: Americas, Greenland, Kingatak Island, Inuit, mid - late 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Kingatak Island, Greenland, North America
physical_description: Leather and sealskin; bone stretcher, ivory fastenings
interpretation: The making and wearing of clothing and accessories changed seasonally. Clothing was made during the relevant hunting period. Caribou fur made lightweight and insulating clothing to be worn when it was cold and dry. Seal-fur clothing was waterproof and made after hunting on the ice.

title: Coat
description: Woman's parka or coat, of young reindeer skin, wolverine fur, wolf's hair, ermine skin, an eagle feather and tags of babiche: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Mackenzie Territory, Peel River, Mackenzie Delta Inuit
production_information: Unknown, Peel River, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
style_culture: Arctic, Inuit, Mackenzie Delta Inuit, Athapaskan
physical_description: Reindeer skin, wolverine fur, wolf's hair, ermine skin, eagle feather, tags of babiche
interpretation: Inuit women of the territory around the Mackenzie River delta wore fine clothing with harmonious and detailed patterning of wolverine, wolf and ermine furs.
references: Listed on Yukon government 'Searching for Our Heritage' project website listing Yukon First Nations artefacts around the world: http://www.tc.gov.yk.ca/museum_resources.html
collection_places: Peel River, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America

title: Oomiak
description: Flat bottomed model oomiak (boat), of sealskin, stretched over a wooden framework, commissioned by Isobel Wylie Hutchison: North America, South Greenland, Nanortalik, Kalaallit, c. 1927
production_information: Unknown, Nanortalik, South Greenland, Greenland, North America
physical_description: Sealskin stretched over a wooden framework
interpretation: The umiaq is a large flat-bottomed boat used throughout the Arctic. In Greenland, umiaqs are crewed by woman, shown here wearing distinctive traditional dress.
associations: Previous owner: Hutchison, Isobel Wylie, Miss, 1889 - 1982
collection_places: Nanortalik, South Greenland, Greenland, North America

title: Ear ornament
description: Ear ornaments, of ivory, with pendants of glass beads united by a string of beads: North America, USA, Alaska, Nunivak Island, Yup'ik, 1930s
production_information: Unknown, Nunivak Island, Aleutian Islands, Alaska, USA, North America
physical_description: Ivory with pendants of glass beads
interpretation: Jewellery honoured the souls of animals, enchanting them with pleasing sounds or lulling them to be hunted. It was worn as decoration and for protection. Before the trade in beads and metal, jewellery was made of animal fur, bones, teeth and claws.
collection_places: Nunivak Island, Alaska, USA, North America

title: Mask
description: Composite mask, representing half-human, half-animal spirits, wood and feather: North America, USA, Alaska, Nunivak Island, Yup'ik, 1930s
production_information: Unknown, Nunivak Island, Aleutian Islands, Alaska, USA, North America
physical_description: Wood, painted white, blue and black
interpretation: The Yup'ik believe in beings that straddle different worlds. This mask is of an ircinrrar, a spirit who is half-man and half-wolf.
references: Blodgett, J., The Coming and Going of the Shaman - Eskimo Shamanism and Art, 1979, Winnipeg, The Winnipeg Art Gallery
collection_places: Nunivak Island, Alaska, USA, North America

title: Mask
description: Mask, of wood, of a human face, possibly a breast pendant, may be connected to preparations or celebrations surrounding a whale hunt: North America, USA, Alaska, Inupiat, 1820s
production_information: Unknown, Alaska, USA, North America
physical_description: Wood

exhibitions.name: Heaven and Hell and other worlds of the dead

interpretation: This lifelike mask is possibly a breast pendant. It may be connected to the preparations or celebrations surrounding a whale hunt which, even today, is dangerous and spiritually charged.

title: Drill bow
description: Bow drill, of walrus ivory, engraved on both sides with hunting scenes: North America, USA, Alaska, Inupiat, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Alaska, USA, North America
physical_description: Walrus ivory; engraved on both sides with hunting scenes; attached thong
interpretation: Bow drills were men's tools made of walrus ivory or bone. Generally bow drill handles were plain, but amongst the Inupiat they had detailed personal engravings. These intimate hunting scenes and animal tallies give us a direct insight into Inupiat male experience.

title: Harpoon counterweight
description: Harpoon counterweight, of fossilised walrus ivory, extensively engraved: North America, USA, Alaska, Bering Strait, St Lawrence Island, Ivetok, Old Bering Sea II Inuit, c. 100 - 300 AD
production_information: Unknown, Ivetok, St Lawrence Island, Alaska, USA, North America
physical_description: Walrus ivory
interpretation: Archaeological finds from the Bering Sea region show ivory carving to be an ancient art form in the Arctic. In the 21st century, sculpture remains a vital expression of the importance of beliefs, hunting and the land.
references: Prehistoric Eskimo Ivories; catalogue of the exhibition at Daedalus Ancient Art, New York, 1992, item #6
collection_places: Ivetok, St Lawrence Island, Alaska, USA, North America

title: Kayak
description: Model kayak, of sealskin, with paddles and harpoons: North America, Canada, Baffin Island, Inuit, late 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Baffin Island, Nunavut, Canada, North America
physical_description: Sealskin
interpretation: Men hunted and travelled in kayaks. On Baffin Island, kayaks were used to hunt walruses, seals and beluga whales at the ice floe-edge. The Aleut kayaks, known as baidarkas, were finely engineered and seaworthy. Aleut men honoured the animal spirits with elaborate hunting outfits and visors.
collection_places: Baffin Island, Nunavut, Canada, North America

title: Wound plug
description: Wound plug, one of three wooden plugs attached to each other by hide lashing, carved roughly in the form of a seal or walrus with eyes of blue glass beads: North America, USA, Alaska, Yup'ik or Inupiat, 19th - early 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Alaska, USA, North America
physical_description: Wood; eyes of blue glass beads
interpretation: Specialized tools were used to attract and appease the animals being hunted. Caribou might be lured by a rattle of caribou hoof tips. A scratcher of seal claws would calm nervous seals by imitating their sounds when they were being stalked on the ice. Wound plugs saved precious blood from being wasted.

title: Parka
description: Parka coat, of seal intestine: North America, USA, Alaska, Yup’ik or Inupiat, 1820s
production_information: Unknown, Alaska, USA, North America
physical_description: Seal entrails
interpretation: Carefully sewn and made of sea mammal intestine, this parka is waterproof and was probably used for hunting in kayaks.

title: Spear thrower
description: Spear thrower, of spruce, with hook of ivory and carved back, used for propelling bird darts, etc: North America, USA, Alaska, Prince William Sound, Aleut, late 18th - early 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Prince William Sound, Alaska, USA, North America
interpretation: Spear throwers were used at sea to throw harpoons and darts further and faster, with the advantage that they only needed one hand.
associations: Item probably from collection: Beechey Collection
collection_places: Prince William Sound, Alaska, USA, North America

title: Float
description: Float, of walrus bladder or awak, attached to a bird dart to prevent it sinking: Americas, West Greenland, Niakonnat, Inuit, c. 1862
production_information: Unknown, Niakonnat, Greenland, North America
physical_description: Walrus bladder; attached to a bird dart to prevent it sinking
interpretation: Bladder and seal floats were used when hunting in kayaks. They slowed heavy sea mammals and eased the task of towing them back.

title: Lamp
description: Lamp, of soapstone, semicircular, used for burning seal oil: North America, Canada, Nunavut, Inuit, mid 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Nunavut, Canada, North America
physical_description: Steatite
interpretation: Traditionally, seal blubber was pounded to make seal oil which provided heat and light. Wicks were made of dry moss and the flame was continuously tended.
credit: On loan from The University of Edinburgh

title: Snow goggles
description: Snow goggles, of ivory, with sealskin straps: North America, Canada, Nunavut, Inuit, late 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Nunavut, Canada, North America
physical_description: Ivory, sealskin
interpretation: Long before sunglasses, snowgoggles were used all over the Arctic. One of the dangers of hunting in the North is the intense solar glare reflecting off the snow and ice. This can cause snow-blindness which is debilitating and dangerous. The small slits in the goggles cut down the glare.

title: Labret
description: Labret, of lead, inset with small blue beads: North America, USA, Alaska or Canada, Northwest Territories, Yup’ik or Inuit, pre-1850s
production_information: Unknown, Alaska, USA, North America; Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Lead inset with small blue beads
interpretation: Men and women in the western Arctic had lip piercings and wore lip ornaments, or labrets. Women wore delicate ones above the chin. Men had larger labrets on one or both sides of the lip, identifying them with walruses through the tusks. Those with Chinese blue beads were especially large and impressive.
collection_places: Alaska, USA, North America; Northwest Territories, Canada, North America

title: Harpoon head
description: Harpoon line, of walrus hide, with two harpoon heads, of bone, copper and stone: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories and Nunavut, Inuit, early - mid 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Nunavut, Canada, North America; Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
interpretation: One of the greatest feats of arctic technology is the toggling harpoon developed for hunting sea mammals. The harpoon head snags underneath the skin, detaching itself from the harpoon shaft. This does not kill the animal, but allows it to be retrieved or buoyed using floats.
collection_places: Nunavut, Canada, North America; Northwest Territories, Canada, North America

title: Fish spear
description: Fish spear, comprising a wooden shaft cut short and head consisting of a central bone spike flanked by two divergent prongs of bone with inturned barbs: North America, Canada, Melville Peninsula, Repulse Bay, Inuit, mid 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Repulse Bay, Melville Peninsula, Nunavut, Canada, North America
physical_description: Wooden shaft cut short; head consisting of a central bone spike flanked by two divergent prongs of bone with inturned barbs
interpretation: In the Arctic, wood was scarce, coming as driftwood or scavenged from European ships. Bone and ivory, in contrast, were plentiful, versatile and strong materials. Dr John Rae collected a number of tools that reflect the inventiveness and skill of bone and ivory technology.
associations: Rae of Orkney Collection; Collector: Rae, John, Dr, 1813 - 1893
collection_places: Repulse Bay, Melville Peninsula, Nunavut, Canada, North America
credit: On loan from The University of Edinburgh

title: Spear-head
description: Spear-head or arrow-head, leaf shaped, of opaque white bottle glass with chipped serrated edges: Australasia, Australia, Northern Territory, Australian Aboriginal, 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Northern Territory, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Opaque white bottle glass; chipped serrated edges
interpretation: When Europeans first installed telegraph cables across Australia, they placed broken glass at the bottom of the poles to stop Aboriginal people from stealing porcelain used in the insulators. Aboriginal groups responded by taking the broken glass and adapting it to make ultra-sharp spearheads.

title: Spear-head
description: Spear-head attached to a short wooden handle, leaf shaped, glass, wood and resin: Australasia, Australia, Western Australia, Kimberley, Australian Aboriginal, 19th or 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Kimberley Region, Western Australia, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Chipped bottle glass set in gum
interpretation: This spearhead was made from recycled bottle glass. The serrated edge was created by flaking off pieces of glass with a stick or bone tool.

title: Knife
description: Knife made from a piece of hoop iron partly covered with resin and wound round with cordage: Australasia, Australia, Queensland, Australia Aboriginal, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Queensland, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Hoop iron partly covered with black gum and wound round with cord
interpretation: Iron objects were among the earliest items traded between Europeans and Aboriginal groups. This knife is made from hoop iron, used to bind barrels.

title: Necklace
description: Necklace consisting of small oblongs of pearl shell perforated and strung on cordage: Australasia, Australia, Queensland, Cape York Peninsula, Australian Aboriginal, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Cape York Peninsula, Queensland, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Oblongs of nautilus shell perforated and strung on twine
interpretation: Pearl shell was traded inland from the coast to make jewellery and ornaments. The further away from the coast these ornaments travelled, the more valuable they became.

title: Passport
description: Piece of wood covered with burnt cup and line decoration said to be a passport (marben) permitting inland groups to fish in the sea: Australasia, Australia, Western Australia, Pilbara, Ngarluma, late 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Pilbara, Western Australia, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Wood; covered with burnt cup and line ornamentation
interpretation: This object was described as a 'water passport' when it entered the Museum. It may have been used to cross into another group's territory in order to reach water.
associations: Collector: Clement, Emile Louis Bruno, Dr, 1844 - 1928

title: Emu and Dingo Dreaming
description: Painting entitled 'Emu and Dingo Dreaming', acrylic on canvas: Australasia, Australia, Australian Aboriginal, Anmatyerre, by Raylene Biscoe Nungala, 1988
production_information: Nungala, Raylene Biscoe, 1988 (fl.), Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Acrylic on canvas
interpretation: Aboriginal dot paintings contain patterns and symbols that can be understood by those familiar with Dreaming stories. Here, Raylene Biscoe Nungala has painted a story that relates to emu and dingo ancestors. It is easy to spot the paw prints left by the dingo and the arrow-shaped emu tracks in the centre of the painting. Other designs are less obvious - the 'U' shapes are hunters and next to them are their spears, boomerangs and shields.

title: Mimi Spearing Kangaroo
description: Painting of bark and ochre entitled 'Mimi Spearing Kangaroo': Australasia, Australia, Northern Territory, West Arnhem Land, Goomadeer River, Gunwinggu, by Bobby Barrdjaray Nganjmirra, 1980
production_information: Nganjmirra, Bobby Barrdjaray, 1915 - 1992, Artist, Goomadeer River, Arnhem Land, Northern Territory, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Bark and ochre
interpretation: Aboriginal people have been producing paintings on bark for thousands of years. In this image a kangaroo is being hunted by a mimi or spirit figure. Mimi are very thin and slight and live inside rock crevices. The kangaroo is much larger than the mimi to emphasize that it is the main subject of the painting. The kangaroo's body is divided into sections, each filled with designs similar to those painted on people's bodies in ceremonies.

title: In Dreams the Heart
description: Sculpture entitled 'In Dreams the Heart', in the form of a Queensland shield, made from the metal exterior of a European travelling trunk: Australasia, Australia, Danie Mellor, 2008
production_information: Mellor, Danie, Dr, 1971 (b.), Artist, Queensland, Australia, Australasia
interpretation: Danie Mellor is of Aboriginal and European heritage, including Scottish. This piece is in the form of a shield from the Atherton Tablelands in Queensland. Crafted from reclaimed metal, the ridges and studs on the surface reflect clan and kinship markings painted onto wooden shields, which are carved, decorated and used by initiated men. In the Atherton Tablelands shields possess feminine qualities, so this piece makes connections with Mellor's matrilineal heritage.

title: Standing Stones, Gumbi Gumbi, Stone Tool
description: Mixed media work entitled 'Standing Stones, Gumbi Gumbi, Stone Tool', consisting of earth, graphite, pastel, acrylic, and waxed linen thread on canvas: Australasia, Australia, Queensland, Brisbane, by Judy Watson, Waanyi, 2020
production_information: Watson, Judy, 1959 (b.), Brisbane, Queensland, Australia, Australasia
copyright: © Judy Watson and Milani Gallery, Meeanjin, Brisbane
interpretation: This artwork draws on Judy Watson's Waanyi and European heritage, including Scottish. The background is coloured using earth from Woorabinda, an Aboriginal settlement where some of Watson's ancestors were forcibly relocated. The artwork overlays images of standing stones in Orkney, an Aboriginal axe head held in a UK museum and leaves of a medicinal gumbi gumbi plant to show the artist's layered experiences of land and culture.

title: Club
description: Wooden club with pointed ends and a pandanus shaped ornamentation covered in white ochre at the head: Yirandali, Australasia, Australia, Queensland, 19th or 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Queensland, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Heavy hard wood; shaft carved with lengthwise grooves and ruddled; expansion below upper end carved into a series of knobs and smeared with white pigment
interpretation: Robert Christison (1837-1915), a Scottish farmer and collector, greatly admired the skilfully crafted weapons of the Yirendali people. He brought back a large number of weapons to Scotland from his time in Australia. These clubs were carved from single pieces of hardwood and polished with emu oil.
associations: Previous owner: Society of Antiquaries of Scotland

title: Spear-thrower
description: Wooden spear-thrower with a thin rectangular body and curved ends, one end has a wooden hook fixed with resin, the other has a white shell fixed with resin: Yirandali, Australasia, Australia, Queensland, 19th or 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Queensland, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Reddish brown polished wood with white shell and black gum
interpretation: Christison noted that a Yirendali hunter could launch a spear over 90 meters with this spear thrower.
associations: Previous owner: Society of Antiquaries of Scotland

title: Club
description: Wooden club with pointed end and jagged oval head with central zigzag carving painted in white ochre: Yirandali, Australasia, Australia, Queensland, 19th or 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Queensland, Australia, Australasia
interpretation: Clubs were mainly used in hunting to kill an animal once it had been felled by a spear or boomerang.
associations: Previous owner: Society of Antiquaries of Scotland

title: Toy
description: Weet weet (wooden throwing toy) with a bulbous wooden head attached by sinew and gum to a slender handle: Australasia, Australia, Victoria, Port Phillip, Kulin, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Port Phillip, Victoria, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Wood; spindle-shaped head formed in a piece with the long thin flexible shaft
interpretation: Throwing the weet weet was a popular game among Aboriginal children. Competitions were held to test the skill of participants. Practising how far and how accurately they could throw a weet weet was invaluable preparation for hunting.

title: Toy axe
description: Child's toy axe with basaltic stone blade and circular smooth cutting edge with a handle of Gumwood bent back upon itself, bound by withe cordage and resin: Yirandali, Australasia, Australia, Queensland, 19th or 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Queensland, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Blade of hard greenish stone, handle of bent withy
interpretation: This toy hatchet was donated to the Museum by Robert Christison. It was made in the same way as larger ones and would have allowed children to practise important skills. Hatchets were used for cutting footholds into trees and for splitting open trunks to gather honey.
associations: Previous owner: Society of Antiquaries of Scotland

title: Shield
description: Shield, elliptical, with raised bars on both sides, front bars blackened and scored with lines and the back carved with horizontal and vertical lines and decorated with white and red pigment, handle carved out of whole, wood: Australasia, Australia, Queensland, 19th or 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Queensland, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Pale wood; front bars blackened and scored with lines
interpretation: The back of this shield has been painted with red and white pigment, and is very different to the front. The handle has been carved out of the solid wood.

title: Shield
description: Shield, incised with lines along the whole length, wood: Australasia, Australia, Northern Territory, Australian Aboriginal: Arrernte, 19th or 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Northern Territory, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Ruddled wood; furrowed longitudinally
interpretation: The shallow grooves that run the full length of this shield show the curved cutting edge of the flint used to make them.

title: Boomerang
description: Boomerang with incised markings, wood: Australasia, Australia, Northern Territory, Australian Aboriginal: Arrernte, 19th or 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Northern Territory, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Ruddled wood with incised linear markings
interpretation: Boomerangs have become an Australian icon. The familiar triangle-shaped boomerang is just one of the many forms and styles that exist. Most boomerangs are not designed to return. In the Dreaming, many features of the landscape were formed by boomerangs being thrown, creating mountains, deserts and rivers.

title: Shield
description: Shield (mulga) triangular in section, carved with grooved linear pattern and decorated with red and white pigment, wood: Australasia, Australia, Australian Aboriginal, 19th to 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Wood; surface carved with grooved linear pattern coloured white and red
interpretation: The intricate designs on this parrying shield have been carefully incised in the hardwood and coloured with red and white pigments.

title: Shield
description: Shield (yarra), elliptical with grooved zigzag decoration, banded in front in brown and yellow pigment, wood: Australasia, Australia, Western Australia, Pilbara, Nullagine, possibly Nyamal, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Pilbara, Western Australia, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Light thin wood with grooved zigzag decoration, banded in front in brown and yellow
interpretation: This type of shield comes from Western Australia, but was traded widely. The designs might represent ripple marks on the sand or on water.
associations: Collector: Clement, Emile Louis Bruno, Dr, 1844 - 1928

title: Spear
description: Spear, wood with stone head: Australasia, Australia, Australian Aboriginal, 19th to 20th century
production_information: Unknown, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Wood; firestone head
interpretation: Spears and spear throwers were important in hunting. Using a spear thrower allowed a hunter to launch a spear three times further, making it easier to kill animals from a distance. At close quarters, nothing was more effective than a solid club carved from a single piece of hardwood.

title: Skirt
description: Skirt or apron of emu tail feathers attached to the skin: Australasia, Australia, Victoria, Australian Aboriginal, 1850 - 1860
production_information: Unknown, Victoria, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Emu tail feathers attached to the skin
interpretation: Traditionally, ornaments made from animal teeth, bones and feathers were worn by men and women in ceremonies. Dancers continue to wear bunches of emu feathers in their hair, and on their arms and ankles, to create texture and to emphasize their movements. Larger bunches are tucked into the back of bark belts.

title: Head ornament
description: Head ornament (gnarru) of brown feathers and smaller white feathers tied to a piece of wood, worn in the hair at ceremonies: Australasia, Australia, North West Australia, Australian Aboriginal: Ngarluma, 19th or 20th century
production_information: Unknown, North West Australia, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Yellow feathers attached to a twig
interpretation: This ornament would have been worn in the hair at ceremonies.

title: Belt
description: Belt, decorated with red pigment and a pattern of alternating panels of horizontal lozenges and vertical stripes, all in white cross hatching and broken lines, bark: Australasia, Australia, North West Australia, Australian Aboriginal, 19th or 20th century
production_information: Unknown, North West Australia, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Bark; painted red and decorated with a pattern of horizontal lozenges and vertical stripes in white cross hatching and broken lines
interpretation: This expandable bark belt would have belonged to an initiated man. Aboriginal children are initiated between the ages of ten and sixteen - when they have proven themselves ready for the responsibilities of adulthood.

title: Ochre
description: Jar of yellow ochre (burdungu) used for painting the chest during ceremony: Australasia, Australia, Western Australia, Ngarluma or Yindjibarndi, 19th century
production_information: Unknown, Western Australia, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: A jar of yellow ochre (burdungu) used for painting the chest during ceremony
interpretation: Pieces of coloured pigment have been found at the earliest archaeological sites in Australia, suggesting that people have painted their bodies for thousands of years. Special designs are applied with paint made from pigments mixed with water. Designs may relate to Dreaming ancestors and their journeys across the land, or to a person's social position.
associations: Collector: Clement, Emile Louis Bruno, Dr, 1844 - 1928

title: Necklace
description: Kangaroo incisor ornament of eighty-eight kangaroo teeth suspended from a strip of dressed kangaroo skin by loops: Australasia, Australia, Victoria, Australian Aboriginal, 1850 - 1860
production_information: Unknown, Victoria, Australia, Australasia
physical_description: Kangaroo teeth and skin, leather loops
interpretation: This piece was made from 88 kangaroo teeth. It would have been worn as a head ornament or as a necklace.

title: Needle-case
description: Woman's needle-case, of ivory, with Chinese blue beads: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Mackenzie River, Inuit, c. 1864
production_information: Unknown, Mackenzie River, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Ivory
interpretation: A variety of specialized women's tools are used to remove blubber, stretch, scrape and cut skins. In the past, men carefully made knives and scrapers, designing them for the comfort of women's hands. Needles, which were very valuable, were safely stored in decorated wood or ivory tubes.
collection_places: Mackenzie River, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America

title: Porcupine quill
description: Selection of porcupine quills, plain and dyed: North America, Canada, Northwest Territories, Dene, c. 1862
production_information: Unknown, Northwest Territories, Canada, North America
physical_description: Plain and dyed porcupine quills: white, dark blue and light blue from indigo, dark green and light green from indigo and turmeric, yellow from turmeric, orange, scarlet from cochineal.
interpretation: Quills were harvested from porcupines. Dene women prepared the quills by washing them to remove the grease, then drying them and sorting them by size. Using berries, lichens and flowers, they dyed the quills a range of colours. Once fur traders introduced commercial dyes, quillworkers preferred these.
references: Idiens, Dale, A catalogue of Northern Athapaskan Indian artefacts in the collection of the Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh, Royal Scottish Museum Information Series, Art and Archaeology 3, March 1979
